headline: Refugee Crisis Fuels European Fears On Terrorism
short descr: A Pew Research Center study shows negative views extend beyond security considerations to economic concerns.
image_caption(s): The Pew Research Center study finds many Europeans believe refugees are linked to terrorism and that only a minority of those surveyed believe diversity makes their country a better place to live.
article: The resurgence of nationalist sentiment that catalyzed Britainâ€™s EU referendum is prevalent in other European nations, Pew research released on Monday shows. Itâ€™s linked overwhelmingly to fears of increasing refugee populations, terrorism and resistance to cultural diversity, according to the survey of people in 10 different European countries.Pew found that majorities in eight nations researchers questioned believed refugees increased the likelihood of terrorism in their country. This sentiment echoes those expressed in the wake of the attacks on Paris in November and Brussels in March, at a time when there had been a surge in arrivals of migrants and refugees across European Union-member countries.â€œThe criticism of the way the EU has handled the refugee crisis has penetrated all the way to Sweden,â€ said Bruce Stokes, director of global economic attitudes at Pew. â€œThat shows how deeply upset people across Europe are with the handling of this issue.â€The negative perceptions extend beyond security considerations to economic concerns â€• 50 percent or more of respondents in half of the nations polled believe refugees will take away jobs and social benefits. When it comes to crime, the link to refugees is far less salient. However, almost half of respondents in Italy and Sweden believe that â€œrefugees are more to blame for crime than other groups.â€ Meanwhile, well over half of Europeans in Hungary (72 percent), Italy (69 percent), Poland (66 percent), and Greece (65 percent) have unfavorable views of Muslims living in their country. In every country polled, the dominant view is that Muslims want to be distinct from larger society, rather than to adapt to European customs. However, Europeans seem split when it comes to explicitly associating these groups with the Islamic State militant group, also known as ISIS. Fewer than half of respondents in every country polled agreed with the statement that â€œMuslims in our country support extremist groups like the Islamic militant group in Iraq and Syria known as ISIS.â€ But in half of the countries polled, a quarter or more of respondents believed that many or most Muslims do support the extremist group.  These findings highlight an ideological divide in Europe. People with a conservative viewpoint in 9 of the 10 countries surveyed had a more unfavorable view toward Muslims. The disparity between people with right- and left-wing views in Greece and Germany, for instance, spans 30 or more points.This ideological divide also translates to perceptions of a diverse society. Only a minority of European respondents in all nations surveyed believed diversity made their country a better place to live.Those who hold conservative views are significantly more likely than those with more liberal views to say that growing diversity makes their country â€œa worse place to liveâ€. When broken down by nationality, over half of Greeks and Italians and about 4 in 10 Hungarians and Poles said growing diversity is detrimental. Europeansâ€™ views on diversity are in contrast to those Americans held in a Pew study released in March. Over half of Americans said having â€œmore people of many different races, ethnic groups, and nationalitiesâ€ makes the U.S. a better place to live, according to the survey. Only 7 percent of Americans said a diverse society makes life worse. The Pew Research Center study was conducted from April 4 to May 12 among 11,494 people in Europe and the United States. The margin of error ranged from 3.1 to 4.6 percent.

headline: Austria Seizing House Where Hitler Was Born To Prevent Nazi Pilgrimage Site
short descr: The country's Interior Minister said he hopes to have it demolished.
image_caption(s): The Austrian government is working to take ownership of the house where Adolf Hitler was born.
article: VIENNA (Reuters) - Austriaâ€™s government moved on Tuesday to seize the house where Adolf Hitler was born to prevent it becoming a site of pilgrimage for neo-Nazis, and the countryâ€™s Interior Minister said he wanted to tear it down.Hitlerâ€™s family lived in the house in Braunau on the Inn for only three years around his birth on April 20, 1889; but the fate of the three-storey building coated in pale yellow paint has long been the subject of controversy.A spokesman for the interior ministry said the government had agreed a law to take ownership after the buildingâ€™s landlord, a local woman, had refused to sell it to the state. The bill would now go before parliament.â€œThe decision is necessary because the Republic would like to prevent this house from becoming a â€˜cult siteâ€™ for neo-Nazis in any way, which it has been repeatedly in the past, when people gathered there to shout slogans,â€ Interior Minister Wolfgang Sobotka told reporters before the cabinet meeting.â€œIt is my vision to tear down the house,â€ he added. A commission consisting of 12 members from the fields of politics, administration, academia and civic society will ultimately decide the fate of the building.A retired local woman owns the property, which Austriaâ€™s interior ministry has been renting since 1972 and has sublet to Braunau. The ministry pays around 4,800 euros ($5,332) a month in rent.The building has housed workshops for disabled people, but has been empty since 2011, because the owner repeatedly rejected ideas for the future use of the house and purchase offers from the state, according to the interior ministry spokesman.Once the law has passed parliament, the owner has no right to appeal the decision or negotiate her compensation, which will be in line with the sum paid to home owners evicted in the course of railway line construction, he said.Nazi Germany annexed Austria in 1938. Debate still smolders over whether Austrians were willing accomplices, many having cheered his return to his country of birth at the time, or the first victims of a dictatorship that ultimately reduced much of Europe to ruins and cost tens of millions of lives.

headline: NYPD Officer Stripped Of Badge, Gun After Deadly Road-Rage Shooting
short descr: Surveillance video has raised doubts about officer Wayne Isaacs' claim that he fired in self defense after being punched.
image_caption(s): Surveillance video appears to show Delrawn Small approaching off-duty NYPD officer Wayne Isaacs' car on July 4.
article: A New York City police officer has been stripped of his badge and gun days after video evidence raised questions about his account of a deadly off-duty shooting.Police officials say that officer Wayne Isaacs is on modified desk duty pending an investigation by the state attorney generalâ€™s office into the fatal July 4 shooting of Delrawn Small, 37, The Associated Press reported Monday.Isaacs, also 37, reportedly told police he fatally shot Small because heâ€™d reached through Isaacsâ€™ car window and punched the off-duty officer at least twice in the face during a road-rage scuffle in Brooklyn.But surveillance video obtained by the New York Post and released last Friday appears to show Isaacs shooting Small as soon as he approaches his window, casting doubt on the officerâ€™s version of events. In the black and white footage above, Small can be seen stumbling away from Isaacsâ€™ car and falling into the road after being shot. The off-duty officer then gets out of his car and appears to briefly stand over Small before returning to his vehicle. â€œThere is clearly not enough time for [Isaacs] to have been punched,â€ the Rev. Al Sharpton told the New York Daily News after reviewing the video. â€œThis is absolutely the opposite of what the policeman said.â€The video sparked a public outcry in a week that saw two other black men killed by officers in Louisiana and Minnesota, and five police officers killed by a sniper in Dallas.Both Small and Isaacs are black, but Sharpton said that didnâ€™t alter the urgency of protestersâ€™ calls for justice and accountability.â€œWe are not against black cops or white cops â€” we are against wrong cops,â€ Sharpton told the Daily News. â€œThis cop told a story that is wrong and someone lost their life. If he told a story that doesnâ€™t stand up about his alibi, why should we believe anything else he says? He killed a man.â€Many protesters carried â€œBlack Lives Matterâ€ signs, as well as signs reading â€œProsecute Killer Cops,â€ â€œDonâ€™t Shootâ€ and â€œAgainst Police Tyranny.â€New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has vowed a â€œfull, fair and independent investigation of this tragedy.â€â€œAs our investigation continues, we urge any witnesses who may have additional information to come forward to our office. My heart goes out to the Small family during this painful period,â€ he said in a release.

headline: Larry Birkhead Helps Anna Nicole Smithâ€™s Daughter Remember Her Late Mom
short descr: Smith died five months after her daughter, Dannielynn, was born.
image_caption(s): Dannielynn Birkhead and Larry Birkhead attend attends the 142nd Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on May 7, 2016 in Louisville, Kentucky.
article: Larry Birkhead is trying to give his daughter, Dannielynn, the most â€œnormalâ€ childhood possible after the death of her mother, Anna Nicole Smith, nine years ago. In a clip from an upcoming episode of â€œThe Steve Harvey Showâ€ airing Tuesday, Birkhead talks about raising his daughter without Smith and reveals just how much Dannielynn knows about her late mother. â€œShe knows that her mom was famous and that people want to know about her,â€ Birkhead said. â€œSo, you know, itâ€™s different for her, my daughter, because itâ€™s nothing for her to go past and see a story in the checkout stands on the cover of magazines of her mom or herself or us or whatever. And itâ€™s a little different than your normal situation, but we make it â€• I make it â€• as normal as I can.â€Smith gave birth to Dannielynn on Sept. 7, 2007, just three days before her 20-year-old son Daniel died of an accidental drug overdose. Tragically, the model would suffer a similar fate. Smith died from a prescription drug overdose only five months later.Comedian Margaret Cho recently opened up about her friendâ€™s death in an April interview with Maria Menounos. â€œI think that her grief was overwhelming,â€ Cho said. â€œHer son had died, and her son was just so precious to her.â€ The comedian added that Smithâ€™s death was probably a result of postpartum depression and guilt stemming from her sonâ€™s overdose.â€œThey both had an issue with prescription painkillers and different drugs like that,â€ Cho said. â€œI donâ€™t know if thereâ€™s anybody thatâ€™s necessarily at fault. Of course, weâ€™re all guilty. Anybody thatâ€™s close to her is guilty, if anyone.â€

headline: Major Wall Street Bank Is Giving Its Low-Wage Workers A Raise
short descr: "Wages for many Americans have gone nowhere for too long," JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon says.
image_caption(s): Jamie Dimon, chairman and chief executive of J.P. Morgan Chase, says the bank's pay increase for its lowest paid employees is the right thing to do in an era when pay has not risen for most people.
article: JPMorgan Chase will give its lowest paid employees a raise over the next two years, its chairman and chief executive Jamie Dimon wrote in an opinion piece for The New York Times on Tuesday.The bank currently has a minimum wage of $10.15 an hour plus benefits. Over the next two years, it will raise base pay to between $12 and $16.50 an hour â€œdepending on geographic and market factors,â€ Dimon writes. The current federal minimum wage is $7.25 an hour, a rate that has not risen since 2009. Twenty-nine states and the District of Columbia have minimum wages above the federal rate. JPMorgan Chaseâ€™s move is the right thing for the company to do in an era when pay has not risen for most people, Dimon said.â€œWages for many Americans have gone nowhere for too long,â€ he wrote.Dimonâ€™s pay package was $27 million for 2015, a 35 percent rise from 2014.His column draws attention to the lower-paid Americans who work in the financial sector. A third of the 1.7 million workers in retail banking make less than $15 an hour, according to a 2015 study flagged in the Financial Times. And a third of bank tellers make so little that they receive some form of public aid, a 2013 study found. The move puts Dimon and JPMorgan Chase in basic agreement with the â€œFight For $15â€ movement, which has advocated for a $15 an hour minimum wage. Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Seattle have passed laws that will raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour over time. J.P. Morgan said in a release that its minimum wage in New York City and San Francisco will be $16.50 an hour in 2019. Workers in Chicago, Los Angeles, Seattle and Washington, D.C., will make $15 in 2019.Of the 18,000 workers at the company who will receive a pay boost, Dimon said many were customer service representative and bank tellers. J.P. Morgan Chase announced last May that it would cut 5,000 employees in the next year. Dimon said at the time that the average JPMorgan Chase branch would lose two bank tellers, The Wall Street Journal reported. The job losses come as the bank increases automation and electronic banking. â€œItâ€™s cheaper for us and good for clients,â€ he said, according to the WSJ. This story has been updated with city-specific salary information from a JPMorgan press release.

headline: 2 Bailiffs Killed In Michigan Courthouse Shooting: Sheriff
short descr: An inmate grabbed an officer's gun and opened fire.
image_caption(s): Larry Darnell Gordon was killed on Monday while trying to escape from a western Michigan courthouse.
article: Two bailiffs were killed in a shooting at a county courthouse in western Michigan on Monday after an inmate grabbed an officerâ€™s gun, the local sheriff said.Berrien County Sheriff Paul Bailey said Larry Darnell Gordon, 45, of Coloma, Michigan, was shot and killed by officers during the incident. The shooting happened while bailiffs were removing the inmate from a holding cell for an unspecified court appearance at the Berrien County Courthouse in St. Joseph. The inmate wrested a gun from one of the officers and began shooting, Bailey said.Joe Zangaro, 61, head of courthouse security, and Ron Kienzle, 63, who had been with the court since 2005, were both slain, ABC7 reported.â€œOur hearts are torn apart,â€ Bailey said at a news conference Monday evening. â€œThey were my friends, they were my colleagues.â€The suspect opened fire around 2:30 p.m., according to TV station WZZM. The shooting started on the third floor of the courthouse, sending people inside the building scrambling for shelter.â€œBrave officers were able to come to their rescue and take the shooter down,â€ Bailey said.The sheriff said a civilian was shot in the arm in a hallway outside the holding area.Gov. Rick Snyder tweeted earlier Monday that Michigan State Police were involved in the investigation, and he asked for people to â€œplease join me in praying for those affected.â€St. Joseph is a small lakefront city roughly 100 miles east of Chicago.CORRECTION: A previous version of this story incorrectly stated Gordon was from Coloma, Minnesota. He was from Coloma, Michigan.

headline: New York Liberty Players Wear #BlackLivesMatter Shirts Before Their Game
short descr: The shirts also paid tribute to the Dallas police officers who died last week.
image_caption(s): New York Liberty players wore shirts honoring last week's shooting victims prior to their game Sunday at Madison Square Garden.
article: Standing in the mecca of basketball on Sunday afternoon, members of the New York Liberty donned warmup shirts memorializing and mourning the victims of last weekâ€™s police shootings featuring the hashtags #BlackLivesMatter and #Dallas5.According to longtime league star Swin Cash, the decision to take a public stand â€• and to become part of an increasingly loud subset of athletes embracing center-stage activist roles â€• was spurred by organic conversations happening between team members and in the WNBA as a whole.As tragedy after tragedy elapsed over the past week, the Liberty realized just how important it was to use their platform to plead for peace.â€œFor us collectively as a group, we decided this is something that we needed to do, wanted to do, and do it here today in New York,â€ Cash said after the game.The decision to honor Alton Sterling and Philando Castile, who died in confrontations with police, along with the five Dallas police officers killed Thursday by a sniper was both intentional and central to the playersâ€™ message. According to the players who spoke Sunday, the team aimed to promote a message of unity and cohesion, hoping to inspire a movement to effect peaceful systemic change.â€œI think itâ€™s a shame that we keep seeing people that want to make this movement as something thatâ€™s violent,â€ Cash said. â€œFive cops gave their lives up trying to protect a peaceful movement. And in this country, I do believe that you can assemble peacefully and protest against injustice.â€The Liberty players joined a long list of athletes whoâ€™ve spoken up about the shootings witnessed over the past week. LeBron James, Carmelo Anthony, members of the U.S. womenâ€™s national soccer team and dozens of others used social media to beg for an end to the violence while the WNBAâ€™s Minnesota Lynx also wore warmups dedicated to those who died.After the contest, New Yorkâ€™s Tina Charles and Carolyn Swords both reiterated the responsibility athletes have to use their public persona for good â€• to â€œengage inâ€ and â€œigniteâ€ conversation, thereby â€œmak[ing] change,â€ as Swords phrased it.While WNBA brass wasnâ€™t made aware of the shirts prior to Sundayâ€™s game, per The New York Times, potential fines and slaps on the wrist from the league office are not the things worrying Cash and her teammates. What worries them â€• and what motivates them â€• seems instead to be the consequences of inaction around the Black Lives Matter movement.â€œ[And] until the system transforms, we cannot sit here and act like there is not a problem here in America,â€ Cash added.

headline: Federal Judge Says Dump Trumpers Don't Risk Going To Jail
short descr: Delegates trying to deny Donald Trump the nomination at the GOP convention just got a boost.
image_caption(s): Delegates cannot be prosecuted for reneging on obligations to support Donald Trump at the Republican National Convention, a federal judge in Virginia ruled Monday.
article: CLEVELAND â€• Republicans considering reneging on their obligation to vote for Donald Trump donâ€™t have to worry about going to jail anymore, thanks to a federal judge.In a 65-page decision released Monday, U.S. District Court Judge Robert Payne struck down a Virginia law that requires all Republican and Democratic delegates to support the respective winners of the state primary under threat of criminal prosecution.Payne agreed with Virginia delegate Beau Correll that the law violates previous Supreme Court rulings that states canâ€™t interfere with the functioning of national political parties.â€œItâ€™s an amazing ruling. What it will do is change the dynamics of the convention,â€ said Dane Waters, head of Delegates Unbound, a group thatâ€™s trying to deny Trump the GOP presidential nomination at next weekâ€™s Republican National Convention.Nearly two dozen other states have similar laws requiring delegates to vote a certain way. Payneâ€™s decision throws the validity of all of them into doubt.â€œIt is a repudiation of Trumpâ€™s efforts to stifle the ability of delegates to vote their conscience,â€ Waters said.Trumpâ€™s supporters had opposed Correll at a hearing Payne held last week in Richmond â€• proof, Waters said, that the Trump campaign understands that delegates will dump Trump if itâ€™s allowed.The Trump campaign did not respond to The Huffington Postâ€™s questions about the ruling. But campaign staffers have been contacting delegates to make sure they will honor Republican National Committee rules that require them to vote according to the results of primaries and caucuses in their states.One top RNC official familiar with the discussion over these rules said Mondayâ€™s decision gives Trumpâ€™s opponents some favorable publicity, but doesnâ€™t alter the underlying numbers. â€œThe PR value of the opinion is greater than the legal effect,â€ the official told HuffPost on condition of anonymity to describe internal matters. â€œThe RNC rules are still the rules.â€Members of Delegates Unbound and Free the Delegates are working to modify the convention rules to let the 2,472 convention delegates vote without regard to how their states and congressional districts voted.But many of the RNC members assembling for a week of committee meetings said the anti-Trump activists simply do not have the votes they need. â€œItâ€™s going nowhere,â€ said Peter Feaman, an RNC member from Florida.Editorâ€™s note: Donald Trump regularly incites political violence and is a serial liar, rampant xenophobe, racist, misogynist and birther who has repeatedly pledged to ban all Muslims â€• 1.6 billion members of an entire religion â€• from entering the U.S.

headline: Actually, Democrats Still Love Each Other XOXO
short descr: And they're not psyched about corporate power.
image_caption(s): Supporters of Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are working it out in the party platform.
article: Youâ€™ve read the stories. The HillaryBots just hate the BernieBros, and the feeling is so, so mutual.Yeah, whatevz. Take a look at this video from the official Democratic Party platform meeting in Orlando, Florida. Theyâ€™re â€œdebatingâ€ antitrust language, establishing the partyâ€™s official stance on heavy concentrations of corporate power. Behold the great conflict of our times, the rending of a once-great political institution as it â€¦ unanimously agrees about something. Watch different factions of the Democratic Party hug each other over a shared commitment to curbing corporate power in the video below:Some variety of antitrust language appeared in the Democratic Party platform from the days of President Grover Cleveland in the late 19th century until the failed presidential bid of Michael Dukakis in 1988. It vanished in 1992 during the nomination of Bill Clinton, who ran on a corporate-friendly platform.So when Sen. Bernie Sandersâ€™ delegates try to resurrect some kind of pro-antitrust stance in the very year that Bill Clintonâ€™s wife is set to take the partyâ€™s presidential nomination, surely this affront will wreak intraparty havoc.That, or a total lovefest.Sanders delegate Mary Bottari, a longtime progressive activist from Madison, Wisconsin, found common cause with former Sen. Mark Pryor (D-Ark.). Pryor was not exactly viewed as a left-wing hero during his days in the upper chamber. He opposed same-sex marriage and was occasionally referred to as â€œthe senator from Walmartâ€ before losing his re-election bid in 2014.But Pryor and Bottari worked out mutually acceptable language aimed at taking down corporate power before delegates formally met to debate the issue. Bottari had pushed for a stronger stance, informed by the work of Barry Lynn, who runs the antitrust wing of the nonpartisan New America Foundation. Pryor, a Clinton delegate, wanted a more moderate tone.They decided on this:We support the historic purpose of the antitrust laws to protect competition, and against the sort of excessively consolidated economic and political power which can be corrosive to a healthy democracy. We support reinvigorating DOJ and FTC enforcement of antitrust laws to prevent abusive behavior by dominant companies, and protecting the public interest against abusive, discriminatory, and unfair methods of commerce. We support President Obamaâ€™s recent Executive Order, directing all agencies to identify specific actions they can take in their areas of jurisdiction to detect anticompetitive practices â€• such as tying arrangements, price fixing, and exclusionary conduct â€• and refer practices that appear to violate federal antitrust law to the DOJ and FTC.Note the reference to â€œreinvigoratingâ€ enforcement, which suggests that Obamaâ€™s antitrust regulation has been weak, alongside the praise for his recent executive order, which suggests that even the president wants to do better. This is the language of reconciliation. It acknowledges shortcomings without foreclosing the possibility that people of good will can do better together. When Pryor took the mic after unanimous approval of the amendment, he addressed both Bottari and the broader audience in Orlando.â€œLet me just say one quick word, if I may, to the Bernie Sanders supporters here,â€ Pryor said. â€œLet me just say Iâ€™m a lifelong Democrat, and I am glad to have you here. Weâ€™re glad to have you in the party. Youâ€™ve made a big difference in 2016. Thank you for being here today, thank you for participating and thank you for the unity.â€Man. These two teams just donâ€™t like each other.

headline: Carrie Budoff Brown Named Politico's Next Editor
short descr: The newsroom veteran has "Politico in her blood," says co-founder John Harris.
image_caption(s): Carrie Budoff Brown will become Politico's next editor.
article: NEW YORK â€• Politico has named Carrie Budoff Brown the publicationâ€™s next editor, succeeding Susan Glasser, who had previously announced plans to move to Israel after the 2016 election.John Harris, who co-founded Politico in 2007 and currently serves as publisher and editor-in-chief, described Budoff Brown in a staff memo as having the politics and policy outlet â€œin her blood, and her passion and protectiveness is like that of a parent for a child.â€Budoff Brown is one of Politicoâ€™s longest-serving employees, having joined the newsroom on the day it launched in January 2007. Sheâ€™s lived through Politicoâ€™s transformation from scrappy website and Hill-centric newspaper to a politics and policy powerhouse boasting over 250 staffers in Washington, along with outposts in New York and Europe.After covering the 2008 campaign, Budoff Brown jumped to the White House beat through 2014. She headed to Brussels to join Politico Europe, which launched in spring 2015, initially as associate editor and senior policy reporter, but was soon promoted to managing editor.The Huffington Post reported last month that Harris was hoping to choose Politicoâ€™s next editor before the political conventions, which begin Monday in Cleveland, and that Budoff Brown was one of the companyâ€™s top internal candidates.There were doubts among Politico staffers that Budoff Brown would return to the states so soon after moving to Europe â€• even if offered such a prestigious post. But buzz inside Politicoâ€™s Rosslyn newsroom over the past week signaled Budoff Brown was the leading contender. The New York Times reported Monday she was getting the job just before the companyâ€™s top brass kicked off a newsroom meeting to officially announce it. In Mondayâ€™s memo, Harris wrote that Glasser would still remain in charge of Politicoâ€™s coverage through the presidential election before becoming a foreign affairs columnist. headline: Manhattanhenge Returns To The Big Apple For The Last Time In 2016

article: Happy Manhattanhenge!The spectacular sunset that aligns perfectly with Manhattanâ€™s street grid returns to New York City on Monday and Tuesday at 8:20 p.m. ET. These are the last times to see the semiannual phenomenon in 2016.Manhattanhenge creates â€œa radiant glow of light across Manhattanâ€™s brick and steel canyons, simultaneously illuminating both the north and south sides of every cross street of the boroughâ€™s grid.â€ At least thatâ€™s how astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson has described the phenomenon. And it was Tyson, a native Manhattanite, who first popularized the term â€œManhattanhenge.â€Manhattanhenge â€• the name is a nod to the prehistoric monument Stonehenge, which was built to align with the rising sun during the summer solstice â€• occurs because of the roughly east-west alignment of the boroughâ€™s street grid. headline: Before SCOTUS Blockade, This GOP Senator Wanted Obama To Hurry Up And Fill Federal Vacancies
short descr: Ron Johnson said last year that presidents should fill vacancies within 210 days.

article: WASHINGTON â€• Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) wonâ€™t help to advance President Barack Obamaâ€™s Supreme Court nominee. Heâ€™s been pretty blunt about wanting Donald Trump to be the next president, and about letting him appoint someone more conservative to the court.â€œTrust me. We will not allow the Supreme Court to flip,â€ Johnson said in March.But before the Supreme Court seat opened up this year, the senator considered filling federal vacancies to be more urgent. In June 2015, when the Senate was debating the National Defense Authorization Act, Johnson offered an amendment underscoring that Obama should have to fill federal posts within 210 days of a vacancy opening up.Hereâ€™s the key passage in his amendment:It is the sense of the Senate thatâ€• (1) the President should comply with the Federal Vacancies Reform Act of 1998 and fill vacancies of Presidentially-appointed positions, including Inspectors General, within 210 days of the position becoming vacant;Obama nominated Merrick Garland in March to replace Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, who died on Feb. 13. That means, by Johnsonâ€™s metric, the Senate should be voting to fill the seat before Sept. 10. But Republicans have given no indication theyâ€™ll give Garland a hearing, never mind a vote, which would mean the Supreme Court seat staying empty for hundreds of days.A Johnson spokeswoman did not respond to a request for comment on how the senator squares his efforts to leave the Supreme Court seat empty with his previous push to fill federal vacancies more quickly. Speaking of judges: The Wisconsin senator is also behind the longest circuit court vacancy in the country.Johnson is up for re-election in November. His Democratic challenger, former Sen. Russ Feingold, is currently leading by 11 percentage points, according to HuffPollster.

headline: Kansas Cop Fired After Threatening 5-Year-Old Girl On Facebook
short descr: "Hold her close tonight," the officer wrote on the girl's mother's Facebook page. "It'll be the last time."
image_caption(s): This post on LaNaydra Williams' Facebook page appears to threaten her young daughter.
article: A Kansas police officer has been fired from his post after leaving a comment on a Dallas womanâ€™s Facebook page that threatened her 5-year-old daughter.Facebook user â€œRodney Leeâ€ published the comment at 11:50 p.m. last Thursday on LaNaydra Williamsâ€™ Facebook page. â€œWeâ€™ll see how much her life matters soon..â€ he wrote beneath a two-year-old photo of Williamsâ€™ daughter, India. â€œBetter be careful leaving your info open where she can be found :) hold her close tonight, itâ€™ll be the last time.â€Overland Park Police Chief Francis Donchez Jr. confirmed in a statement that the post was written by one of his officers. Multiple media outlets identified the commenter as Rodney Lee Wilson, but a department spokesperson declined to confirm the officerâ€™s identity to The Huffington Post. (Both the Facebook accounts in question are no longer publicly accessible.) The officer was fired, â€œeffective immediately,â€ Donchez said, and a criminal investigation is underway.â€œI want to assure our community, and those outside our community, that our highest priority is the safety and welfare of the citizens of Overland Park, and the men and women who protect everyone,â€ he said. â€œI will continue to hold the employees of the Overland Park Police Department accountable for its actions on and off-duty.â€Williams told Kansas City NBC affiliate KSHB that she â€œfelt horrifiedâ€ by the officerâ€™s comment, particularly because sheâ€™d never even met him. She said she was worried that he might retaliate if he was fired for his actions.The threatening comment was posted hours after a man assaulted and killed five police officers during a Black Lives Matter protest in Dallas. Protesters were denouncing police brutality after two black men, Alton Sterling and Philando Castile, were fatally shot by police officers in Louisiana and Minnesota.

headline: Trump's Big New Idea For A Veterans Hotline Was Tried Already... By Trump
short descr: It didn't go swimmingly.
image_caption(s): Donald Trump wants a veterans hotline. He proposed one before, and it failed.
article: During a speech on Monday centered around veterans care and reform, Donald Trump said that as president, he would put together a 24-hour hotline to â€œensure no valid complaint about VA and its wrongdoing falls through the cracks.â€ The calls, he said, would be â€œanswered by a real person,â€ and if the complaint was valid and not addressed, it would â€œbe brought directly to me and I will pick up the phone and fix it myself if I have to.â€The presumptive Republican nominee treated the policy prescription as a new one:But itâ€™s not, entirely. Trump debuted a variation of the hotline idea during the Republican primary. It didnâ€™t perform to expectations. In July 2015, the Trump campaign established a phone number and email address for â€œveterans to share their stories about the need to reform our Veterans Administration.â€â€œIf he is elected President he will take care of these and all Veteran complaints very quickly and efficiently like a world-class business man can do, but a politician has no clue,â€ his campaign said in an accompanying Facebook post.The hotline, in short, was a less ambitious version of what Trump is now proposing: a place for people to share stories, but not necessarily facilitate better health care. But even with those limited ambitions, it sputtered. When reporters began trying the hotline, they got an automated message telling them to send an email instead. â€œ[I]t appears that the hotline is no longer accepting calls,â€ reported The Blaze in February. IJ Review had a veteran call the hotline, only to see the call go â€œdirectly to voicemail following a quick reference to the Trump campaign.â€And it appears the hotline hasnâ€™t gotten any better since. The Huffington Post dialed 855-VETS-352 a few times, only to hit the same frustrating wall. We were told to email veterans@donaldtrump.com and were offered the option to press 1 to get back to the main menu. When we did, we got the same exact automated message. We pressed 1 again and the line dropped. So we tried the same exact steps, only this time, we didnâ€™t press 1 on the second go-around. A voice came on the line. â€œThank you for calling,â€ it said, â€œgoodbye.â€Editorâ€™s note: Donald Trump regularly incites political violence and is a serial liar, rampant xenophobe, racist, misogynist and birther who has repeatedly pledged to ban all Muslims â€• 1.6 billion members of an entire religion â€• from entering the U.S.

headline: Flint Fallout Prompts Philadelphia To Do Extra Tests For Lead In Water
short descr: The new round of testing appears to be a response to activist pressure.
image_caption(s): Philadelphia will host the 2016 Democratic National Convention in July. Hillary Clinton, the presumptive nominee, made the water crisis in Flint, Michigan, part of her presidential campaign.
article: Philadelphia announced Friday that it will conduct new tests for lead in the cityâ€™s water, apparently in response to activistsâ€™ cries that the city wasnâ€™t doing enough to assure residents their taps are safe.The cityâ€™s water department said it will collect samples this summer from at least 50 homes classified as having the highest water lead risks. Previously, the city had not planned to do any lead testing this year. Like many big water systems with a history of meeting federal standards, Philadelphia only has to look for lead every three years.Though the department said itâ€™s making the changes because it received updated guidance from the state, the announcement seems designed to ease activist pressure.This summer, for instance, a small band of Philadelphians calling themselves the Philly Unleaded Project plan to independently verify the cityâ€™s assurances.â€œIt came to our attention because of all the stuff that was happening in Flint,â€ Philly Unleadedâ€™s Tony Spagnoli told HuffPost. â€œThat was a really big wake-up call.â€Spagnoli, a 33-year-old urban planner, said he welcomes the cityâ€™s water departmentâ€™s newly announced testing regimen, but heâ€™s not going to call off his independent testing effort. He said he and his team of volunteers hope to get some 400 Philadelphia residents to fill liter bottles from their kitchen sinks this summer. Then theyâ€™ll send the samples to Virginia Techâ€™s lab for analysis by civil engineer Marc Edwards.Why Edwards? Because last summer, Edwards oversaw a similar independent sampling effort in Flint, Michigan, leading him to warn residents not to drink the water because it was tainted with lead, a brain-damaging metal used for water pipes in many American cities. The Michigan government pooh-poohed Edwardsâ€™ warnings, but subsequent testing of Flint kidsâ€™ blood proved him right: There was lead in the water. Edwards is not directing the sampling effort in Philadelphia. And just because the activists want to test the water doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s unsafe â€• just that the city hasnâ€™t done enough to assure them it isnâ€™t. Flintâ€™s water became brown and funky after the state changed the cityâ€™s water source, something very unusual for a water system to do. It was obvious to Flint residents that their water was weird, but the real problem was lead, which is colorless and tasteless. The only way to detect lead in water is by sending the water to a lab. Federal regulations require big cities to test for lead in water samples from peopleâ€™s homes. At least half of those homes are supposed to be connected to water mains via lead service lines, so the sampling pool can give a picture of how bad the lead contamination might be in water from the riskiest possible faucets. But despite an abundance of such homes in the Philadelphia, fewer than half of the cityâ€™s 134 samples taken in 2014 came from high-risk addresses. The cityâ€™s sampling that year showed 90 percent of homes had less than 5 parts per billion of lead in their water, well below the 15 parts per billion threshold set by the Environmental Protection Agency. What Spagnoli wants to know is, what would the numbers be if the city sampled at more sites with lead pipes? Now, the city plans to find out the answer.Avoiding the highest-risk homes is a tactic that actually resulted in criminal charges in Flint. In May, the Michigan attorney general charged two former state officials with several crimes, including a misdemeanor because they failed â€œto collect required samples included in the Tier 1 category of serviced lines.â€Both the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection and the federal Environmental Protection Agency had given their blessing to Philadelphiaâ€™s testing procedures, but in June some Philadelphia residents filed a class-action lawsuit. Among other things, the suit alleges that the cityâ€™s sampling methods are â€œdiluting its testing pool and skewing the results in such a way as to paint a woefully inaccurate picture of the Cityâ€™s overall lead contamination.â€ The case also complains that the cityâ€™s instructions for taking samples arenâ€™t ideal for catching the most lead. The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection, which oversees city water systems throughout the state, recently cited two other Pennsylvania towns for failing to collect samples from the riskiest homes. HuffPost asked the agency why Warwick Township and Lititz Borough received citations for avoiding lead pipe samples, but Philadelphia hasnâ€™t. â€œThere is no one-size-fits all approach to resolving violations, and enforcement actions are taken according to the nature and severity of the violation,â€ spokesman Neil Shader said in an email, noting the agency doesnâ€™t comment on possible future enforcement actions.Activists applauded Philadelphiaâ€™s announcement about the new testing.â€œThis change is very welcome, and also we must keep in mind it is the result of painstaking work by ordinary people who have taken it upon themselves to do oversight,â€ said Yanna Lambrinidou, a water expert and affiliate faculty member at Virginia Tech. Lambrinidou is part of a group of activists and experts that has been pushing the EPA to crack down on Philadelphia. (Lambrinidou said sheâ€™s given informal advice to Philly Unleaded, though she and Edwards arenâ€™t overseeing Spagnoliâ€™s testing drive.)If Philadelphia was not complying with the Safe Drinking Water Act, it wouldnâ€™t make the city that unusual â€• the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental nonprofit, reported last week that more than 5,000 community water systems broke the rules last year, and only 5.7 percent were officially sanctioned by state or federal regulators. Even Flintâ€™s water got a pass under the regulation, at least until the EPA issued an emergency order in January, almost a year after serious problems came to light. The city of Philadelphia has insisted all year that its water is safe to drink because it meets federal standards. In a statement Friday, Water Commissioner Debra McCarty said the agency â€œstrives to go above and beyond for its customers every day.â€But Gary Burlingame, the director of laboratory services for the Philadelphia Water Department, told HuffPost in April that the Flint crisis may have been a bit overblown, and that itâ€™s not clear that drinking water can pose a serious risk of lead exposure.â€œWhat we donâ€™t have from Flint is a peer-reviewed published study to look at the science of Flint,â€ Burlingame said then. â€œAll we have is what the news mediaâ€™s reporting and some of the policy and management issues.â€The blood lead research that forced the government to admit Flintâ€™s water was dangerous actually had been peer-reviewed at the time of Burlingameâ€™s statement. Last month, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention essentially confirmed those findings in a new paper.â€œPublished peer-reviewed papers help put the pieces together, so the nation can understand and apply that understanding,â€ Burlingame said in an emailed statement for this story. â€œThis paper provides an important step in that understanding. We will carefully study this paper â€• and others that we expect have yet to be published â€• involving the science behind Flintâ€™s unfortunate events.â€

article: Glass skateboards may look super slick and cool, but thereâ€™s a painfully obvious reason why theyâ€™re not sold in stores.Unfortunately, these skateboarders apparently didnâ€™t get that memo.Members of YouTube channel Braille Skateboarding recently filmed themselves testing out a custom-made glass deck in a cringeworthy demonstration thatâ€™s part of their â€œYou make it, we skate itâ€ series.The guys took to a skate park where one of them was seen gingerly gliding around the course and even up and down some ramps.When they decided to drop in off the top of a ramp, however, thatâ€™s when things got dicey.Within seconds of lift-off, the deckâ€™s back end is seen snapping off, sending the rider somersaulting and skidding onto the pavement below.Miraculously, he appeared to escape unharmed despite being surrounded by shards of glass.â€œNobody expected that,â€ one of them said â€” amazingly referring to the board breaking, not to his buddyâ€™s lack of injuries.The stuntâ€” which the creators admit in the videoâ€™s title is â€œextremely dangerousâ€â€” has been viewed more than 1.1 million times since its upload on Saturday, making it one of the siteâ€™s top trending videos Monday.One YouTube commenter noted: â€œYou know what they say â€˜Sk8 or die.â€™â€Other popular videos released by the guysâ€™ YouTube channel show them skating on an iPad and a flat screen TV.

headline: This Is The Robot Dallas Police Used To Kill Shooting Suspect
short descr: Major ethical questions remain.
image_caption(s): This Andros Mark V robot isn't the exact robot used in Dallas, but it's the same model. Photographed in Miami in 2009.
article: The Dallas Police Department revealed new details Monday about a robot that was used to kill the suspect in a shooting rampage last week. Police tweeted that the robot was a Remotec Andros Mark V-A1 and not a Model F-5, as previously reported.The robot was used to dispatch a suspect who opened fire during a Black Lives Matter protest, killing five officers and injuring several more. The unit is supposed to be used for bomb disposal, though it was harnessed by police last week to deliver an explosive instead. While the decision kept officers out of harmâ€™s way, some wondered about the implications of police deploying high-tech weapons without oversight. The Andros Mark V-A1, which is made by military tech company Northrop Grumman, contains a surveillance camera and an extendable arm with a rotatable â€œgripper.â€ Itâ€™s controlled wirelessly and can climb up stairs. In this case, it used its gripper to deliver a C4 explosive, which police detonated to kill the suspect.A non-lethal option may not have been possible, said Dr. Robert Latiff, a retired major general of the United States Air Force who now serves as a technology expert at the University of Notre Dame.â€œGiven lots of time â€• which they did not have â€• and resources, the police probably could have disabled the shooter,â€ Latiff told The Huffington Post via email.â€œRemember though, they were in the midst of what would have been a combat situation. While the action they took was admittedly different, and will generate much discussion, I do not see it any differently than if a police marksman had been able to shoot the perpetrator from a distance,â€ he added.In a sense, the Mark V-A1 is a tool like any other. It isnâ€™t some artificially intelligent kill bot like the Terminator. But Illah Nourbakhsh, a professor of robotics at Carnegie Mellon University, warns that ignoring the greater implications of this technologyâ€™s deployment could be disastrous.â€œFuture such robots will have only more bells and whistles, all of which provide the affordance for a whole array of ways in which the robot can perform activities never dreamt of by the engineers, or by the purchasing agents who chose to equip the police department with them,â€ Nourbakhsh told HuffPost via email. â€œThis takes us to a Wild West where sophisticated machines unleash the creative potential of the users.â€There are ethical concerns, he added.â€œThere are no laws, guidelines or oversight processes for killing with a bomb disposal â€˜bot,â€ Nourbakhsh said.The robot was used by Dallas police in a different way than intended. As robots become more advanced, Nourbakhsh argued, the gap between that original design and actual function will widen, which could lead to problems. We see this everywhere in developing technology.Consider your smartphone: When you bought it, even just a couple of years ago, there may not have been an easy way to keep law enforcement from prying into your messages if you became a criminal suspect. Now secure messaging apps are everywhere, potentially transforming your phone into a device with significantly more advanced capabilities than what you paid for.Apply that logic to heavy machinery that can be outfitted with weapons and you might understand what all of the concern is about.

headline: Tim Duncan Retires From The NBA After 19 Seasons
short descr: And he did so in a very Duncan-esque way.
image_caption(s): The San Antonio Spurs' Tim Duncan in Washington, D.C., on Nov. 4, 2015.
article: Tim Duncan, arguably the best power forward to ever play the game of basketball, decided to retire on Monday after 19 seasons in the league.Duncan announced his retirement in a statement released through the San Antonio Spurs organization. In classic team-first, itâ€™s-not-about-me Duncan style, no quotes from him were featured in the Spursâ€™ retirement press release. Over the course of his career, Duncan put together a rÃ©sumÃ© that few have ever matched: five NBA championships, three NBA Finals MVPs, two regular season MVPs, 15 All-Star Game selections, 10 All-NBA First Team selections, one team.But more so, he was known for the modesty, humility and consistency with which he played the game. Nicknamed â€œThe Big Fundamental,â€ Duncan was never flashy and rarely expressive on the court. While other great players of his generation were known for turnaround fadeaways and ferocious dunks, Duncanâ€™s signature shot was a vanilla bank shot from mid-range, which he punished defenders with over and over again during his two-decade career. Duncan never let the opposition get to him, going about his game in the same methodical manner no matter the opponent. And they knew it, too. â€œThe Spurs won because of Tim Duncan, a guy I could never break,â€ Shaquille Oâ€™Neal once said. â€œI could talk trash to Patrick Ewing, get in David Robinsonâ€™s face, get a rise out of Alonzo Mourning, but when I went at Tim heâ€™d look at me like he was bored.â€Off the court, Duncan was understated and unselfish. When told after his team won the 2003 NBA Finals that he had registered 21 points, 20 rebounds, 10 assists and eight blocks in its final game, Duncan simply replied, â€œThatâ€™s cool.â€ When teammate Tony Parker won the NBA Finals MVP in 2007, no one appeared happier for him than Duncan. The Spurs organization knew what it had almost from the beginning. â€œThe chances of us trading Tim Duncan are about the same as (then-scout) R.C. Buford starting at off guard,â€ Spurs coach Gregg Popovich said after the team drafted Duncan No. 1 in the 1997 NBA Draft. As such, the team built around Duncan from the outset, surrounding the Virgin-Islands-born player with teammates that matched him both in skill and personality.Soon, Duncan would become Rookie of the Year. â€œDo I give a speech or something?â€ he joked. Just two years later, he would hoist the teamâ€™s first championship trophy and his own first NBA Finals MVP. The Spurs never missed the playoffs during Duncanâ€™s 19-year career, and Duncanâ€™s statistics remained remarkably consistent through his first 18 seasons, each of those seasons scoring between 17.1 and 22.6 points per 36 minutes and pulling down between 10.5 and 12.2 rebounds.Perhaps even more impressively, they have become known over Duncanâ€™s career as the premiere organization in the league â€• as well as its most international. Few could argue with the idea that Duncan, one of the greatest and most selfless players ever, is the main reason why.

headline: News Outlets Prepare For Possible Unrest At Political Conventions
short descr: A top security firm has trained journalists at nearly two dozen organizations in recent months.
image_caption(s): News organizations are preparing for possible danger at next week's Republican convention in Cleveland as major protests, like this one in Baton Rouge, take place throughout the country.
article: NEW YORK â€• Ferguson. Baltimore. Cleveland?Over the past two years, journalists have been thrust into dangerous reporting situations as militarized police forces have squared off with protesters, evoking scenes more reminiscent of war zones than American cities. The shooting of five police officers Thursday during a Black Lives Matter demonstration in Dallas, followed by the disproportionately aggressive police response toward protesters and journalists over the weekend in Baton Rouge, has only heightened safety concerns for the press heading into next weekâ€™s Republican National Convention in Cleveland. Thousands of protesters and Trump supporters, including a group of white nationalists, are expected to converge on the city. Cleveland will assign about a third of its 1,700-person police force to the convention, while thousands of out-of-town officers will likely be added as reinforcements. The four-day Republican gathering wraps up Thursday, with the Democratic National Convention beginning four days later in Philadelphia. News organizationsâ€™ safety concerns for this two-week stretch have kept veteran journalist and security expert Frank Smyth very busy. Smyth, the founder and executive director of Global Journalist Security, said his group has conducted nearly two-dozen civil unrest trainings for news organizations in recent months. Theyâ€™ve held these four-hour trainings in New York, Washington D.C., Los Angeles and Cleveland, he said. Global Journalist Security offers a two-day, $1,195 course on civil unrest and active shooter situations, the most recent taking place last week in Washington, D.C. Smythâ€™s group also held a four-hour, interactive online course pegged to the conventions on Monday for $495, and has scheduled another for Friday. His team has already scoped out Cleveland for potential flash points, he said, and they plan to offer additional trainings depending on demand.Smyth does not comment on his clients, though a Washington Post spokeswoman confirmed that some of the paperâ€™s staff were doing training sessions with Global Journalist Security.The spokeswoman declined to comment further, and news organizations are broadly reluctant to discuss security protocols. While other outlets are surely taking precautions ahead of Cleveland, most of the more than 12 approached by The Huffington Post offered little about what, specifically, that entails.A New York Times spokeswoman said the paper has â€œresources and procedures in place for NYT staff covering any situation including the upcoming conventions that can present safety challenges.â€â€œGiven recent events it would be irresponsible not to train journalists to be acutely aware of their situations to be prepared for unexpected developments,â€ Mike Oreskes, NPRâ€™s editorial director and senior vice president of news, told HuffPost in an email Monday. â€œWe have a safety advisor who has met with staff and talked about how to best handle volatile situations,â€ Oreskes continued. â€œItâ€™s always better to think ahead and plan. We have provided NPR staff and Member station reporters tips and guidelines that are lessons from people who have covered events ranging from Ferguson to Tahrir Square. headline: Did Ruth Bader Ginsburg Cross The Line With Her Donald Trump Comments?
short descr: Some court observers are crying foul over her comments about the presumptive Republican presidential nominee.
image_caption(s): Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's recent interviews have made it clear where she stands on presumptive GOP nominee Donald Trump.
article: Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg hasnâ€™t been shy in recent days about the prospect of a Donald Trump presidency, joking that she might move to New Zealand if it ever happens.â€œI canâ€™t imagine what this place would be â€• I canâ€™t imagine what the country would be â€• with Donald Trump as our president,â€ Ginsburg told The New York Times in an article published Sunday. â€œFor the country, it could be four years. For the court, it could be â€• I donâ€™t even want to contemplate that.â€That tracks a comment she made in a separate interview with The Associated Press, when the justice stopped short of noting sheâ€™d rather have presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton making future appointments to the Supreme Court.â€œI donâ€™t want to think about that possibility,â€ Ginsburg said when asked to consider Trump in the role of appointer-in-chief. Now a number of legal academics and Supreme Court observers are raising questions about the propriety of Ginsburgâ€™s candor and what it might mean for the courtâ€™s integrity â€• with some suggesting she might have to recuse herself from considering any Trump-related case that reaches the high court.â€œThe other justices should hold an intervention, and tell her to be quiet or step down,â€ wrote Josh Blackman, a Houston College of Law professor who frequently writes about the high court. â€œThis isnâ€™t funny anymore.â€ He added that Ginsburgâ€™s comments are â€œbeyond the pale.â€Rick Hasen, another avid court watcher who specializes in election law, wrote that Ginsburgâ€™s statements could very well lead a â€œreasonable personâ€ to question her impartiality in a future politically charged case.â€œI think this is ultimately a question for judicial ethicists, but I do think following these comments it is a legitimate question to raise, should Donald Trumpâ€™s campaign come to the Court with any legal questions before the election,â€ he wrote in his widely read Election Law Blog.Dmitry Bam, a professor at the University of Maine School of Law who has written on judicial recusals and ethics, said â€œthere is little question that she has crossed a line.â€â€œFor a court that cares a great deal about appearances, this certainly creates the appearance that justices take sides in elections,â€ Bam wrote in an email. â€œAnd if Trump v. Clinton arises in the fall, I would say that there is at the very least an appearance of bias if Justice Ginsburg participates.â€Under federal law, justices must step aside from cases where their â€œimpartiality might reasonably be questionedâ€ â€• and they did so in 180 cases during the courtâ€™s last term, according to a new analysis by Fix the Court, a group that pushes for structural reform at the Supreme Court.Fix the Court found that the bulk of recent recusals were due to the justicesâ€™ prior work as appellate judges or in government positions. Other recusals were related to stock ownership and family ties to judges or lawyers who participated in earlier stages of the cases.But recusals for political views or implicit support for certain positions are exceedingly rare, even in the face of a code of judicial conduct that guides federal judges on extra-judicial activities and how to avoid even the appearance of impropriety.Even with that guidance and other self-imposed checks in place, the justices have time and again declined to step aside in cases of high political salience â€• most recently in the same-sex marriage cases, where Ginsburg and Justices Elena Kagan and Clarence Thomas all took part despite calls for them to recuse.But Ginsburgâ€™s Trump comments â€• as well as her separate endorsement of Merrick Garland, the presidentâ€™s stalled choice to fill the Scalia vacancy â€• may be unprecedented.â€œIâ€™m not aware [that] any justice before has ever commented on the merits or demerits of a presidential candidate,â€ said Ed Whelan, the president of the Ethics and Public Policy Center and a frequent contributor to the conservative National Review Online, where he has chronicled this episode and what he deems Ginsburgâ€™s â€œremarkable record of indiscretions.â€â€œI may very well share her concerns about Donald Trump ... but the ethics concerns donâ€™t depend on the soundness or unsoundness of the candidate,â€ Whelan added.But what if this is less a question about ethics and more about wanting our judges to be candid about their positions and biases â€• and that the political process itself has done away with the veneer that the high court is entirely apolitical?â€œMost people now recognize that judges are heavily influenced by their personal beliefs and experiences,â€ said Bam, of the Maine School of Law.â€œWe have watched one party refuse to hold hearings based the politics of the president and his potential nominees. Judges time their retirements to coincide with a certain party being in office. And the 5-4 decision in Bush v. Gore, along partisan lines, also shows the political nature of the court,â€ Bam said. â€œSo perhaps the pretense that judges are nonpartisan and apolitical does more harm than good.â€

headline: Not All Democrats Think Hillary Clinton Should Be Cleared Of Wrongdoing In Email Scandal
short descr: Some also say the issue makes them worry about her decision-making if she becomes president.
image_caption(s): According to a recent poll, nearly one-third of Democratic respondents say Hillary Clinton's email investigation makes them worry about how she might handle her responsibilities as president.
article: Fifty-six percent of Americans disagree with FBI director James Comeyâ€™s recommendation to clear Hillary Clinton of any wrongdoing for her email practices as secretary of state, according to an ABC/Washington Post poll released on Monday. Unsurprisingly, Republicans are united in their stance on the issue: Eighty-eight percent of those polled disagree with Comeyâ€™s recommendation not to charge Clinton with a crime. But perhaps a less anticipated finding of the poll is that Democrats arenâ€™t completely unified in their perception of the issue. While 6 in 10 Democrats polled agree with Comeyâ€™s recommendation, a significant portion â€• 31 percentâ€• disagree with it. Republican respondents almost unanimously say that the email issue makes them worried about how Clinton will handle responsibilities if she is elected president. Most Democrats polled â€• 68 percent â€• donâ€™t see a connection between how Clinton handled her email and how she would handle her responsibilities as president if she wins. Yet, about one-third of Democratic respondents say the issue does cause them to worry. Independents lean closer to Republicans on the Clinton email issue. About 60 percent of respondents who identify as independents disagree with the recommendation to clear Clinton, and a nearly equal portion express worry about the outcome and what it says about her decision-making if she becomes president.The Washington Postâ€™s Greg Sargent points out there are a striking number of young and liberal voters among those who disagree with Comeyâ€™s decision and worry about Clintonâ€™s decision-making. Sargent suggests that the nearly one-third of Democrats who oppose the majority of their party on the issue might be supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.). There is, however, a silver lining for Clinton to be found in the data. Even though Democrats somewhat disagree on whether Comey made the right call, the ABC/Post poll shows itâ€™s unlikely to dissuade them from voting for Clinton. Seventy-three percent of Democrats polled say the outcome makes no difference in their vote, and 16 percent say it makes them more likely to vote for Clinton. Just 9 percent say the outcome makes them less likely to vote for her.The Huffington Post Pollster general election chart, which aggregates all publicly available polls, shows Clinton leading in the presidential race with 46 percent of the vote to presumptive GOP nominee Donald Trumpâ€™s 40 percent. She also holds 81 percent of the vote among Democrats.  The ABC/Washington Post poll surveyed 519 American adults on July 6-7 using live interviewers. The poll has a 5 percent margin of error.

headline: GOP Platform Committee Bucks 21st Century, Reaffirms Anti-LGBT Stance
short descr: Talk about beating a dead horse.
image_caption(s): The GOP platform subcommittee on health care, education and crime meets in Cleveland.
article: CLEVELAND â€• Republican delegates tasked with drafting the partyâ€™s official platform on Monday rebuffed several efforts aimed at bringing the GOP into the 21st century â€• at least on paper. Instead, GOP officials voted to reaffirm the partyâ€™s opposition to gay adoption, same-sex marriage, abortion and transgender individuals using public restrooms â€• issues that generally have seen great progress in recent years.The Platform Committee, one of several committees meeting prior to next weekâ€™s Republican National Convention, gathered in downtown Cleveland to spell out the partyâ€™s core principles and values for the next four years. The language the committee ultimately settles on is not binding, however â€• officials have ignored its provisions in the past. But the document can help reveal the direction of party, and, especially this year, crystalize the differences between it and its presumptive standard bearer, real estate mogul Donald Trump.Deep in the bowels of the Huntington Convention Center, a subcommittee handling health care, education and crime passed several controversial amendments curtailing LGBT rights, despite protests that the party would unnecessarily alienate voters ahead of the general election. The full committee is set to vote on the changes later in the week.New York delegate Annie Dickerson, a longtime adviser to Paul Singer, a Republican megadonor who has championed gay and lesbian rights, mounted the most strenuous objections to several controversial amendments presented before the committee. Dickerson argued that the party ought to leave such issues to state legislatures in order to avoid antagonizing gay voters. Over and over, however, she was rebuffed by her colleagues, who seemed to be led at times by prominent social conservative and Family Research Council President Tony Perkins.The subcommittee decided to keep language in two separate amendments that calls for legislation to keep transgender people from using public restrooms that align with their gender identity â€• a nod to over 200 bills targeting lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender individuals that were introduced in the 2016 legislative session nationwide.Dickerson protested, noting the committee was even at odds with Trump, who had said he would allow a transgender person in any bathroom at his signature Manhattan property Trump Tower. (He has since reversed his position, however, coming out in support of North Carolinaâ€™s anti-LGBT law.) â€œTalking about bathrooms, it takes away from party in general,â€ Dickerson said, before calling the issue a â€œrabbit hole.â€ â€œFor us to voice this, I think itâ€™ll be wrong for those of us who have gay family members, coworkers, neighbors. They are our friends. It should be about addition, and not subtraction,â€ she later added.Julie Adams, a delegate from Kentucky, agreed. â€œItâ€™s mind-boggling to me that we would elevate it to this extent,â€ she said. â€œI believe the GOP is big tent. I believe this is overkill.â€But North Carolina delegate Mary Forrester wasnâ€™t moved. â€œBathrooms arenâ€™t the issue,â€ she said. â€œIt is locker rooms, dressing rooms.â€ The Tar Heel state has been at the center of the controversy after Gov. Pat McCrory (R) signed an anti-LGBT law earlier this year. He was forced to amend the law, however, after significant outcry from the stateâ€™s businesses community.Perhaps as a recognition of the significance of the vote, Republican National Committee Chair Reince Priebus briefly made an appearance in the back of the room. He did not make remarks, however, preferring to look on silently and huddle with staff outside. Debate over gay adoption took a similar turn. Some subcommittee members pushed for the platform to include an amendment saying â€œa loving and stable homeâ€ was the best place to raise a child â€• rather than its initial assertion that children benefit from homes with a â€œmother and father.â€ â€œI object to allowing discrimination against gays from adopting children. I think this is blatant discrimination. We should support loving adoption,â€ Dickerson said, before seeing yet another amendment aimed at tempering her platform go down in flames.Committee members also clashed over issues of marriage equality and religious liberty. Delegates ultimately voted to retain language calling for a constitutional amendment on same-sex marriage, and reaffirmed their opposition to abortion. Trump, who has said while campaigning that women should face â€œsome sort of punishmentâ€ if they have an abortion, for years supported a womanâ€™s right to do so legally. Retired Gen. Michael Flynn, one of Trumpâ€™s possible vice presidential running mates, has had a similar change of opinion: He called himself â€œpro-lifeâ€ on Monday, one day after saying he believed women had the right to choose. Delegates added to the pile of hot-button topics by unanimously adopting an amendment that called pornography â€œa public health crisisâ€ and â€œpublic menaceâ€ that is destroying lives. The measure went further than the 2012 GOP platform, which mainly focused on problems with child pornography. FRCâ€™s Perkins also succeeded in introducing an amendment to the platform affirming â€œthe right of parents to determine the proper treatment or therapy, for their minor children,â€ a reference to gay conversion therapy, which has been banned in a number of states.When the Restoring Constitutional Government subcommittee met in a convention room, Nevada delegate Jesse Law proposed adding a few words to include LGBT individuals in the section discussing basic rights. One delegate suggested replacing â€œLGBTâ€ with â€œgender,â€ wondering if that wouldnâ€™t cover it. But then a Virginia delegate, saying that he sensed there wasnâ€™t much support in the room for the idea, moved to table Lawâ€™s amendment. More than a dozen delegates chimed in to second that, and it passed by a near unanimous voice vote.Law played down the result in an interview with The Huffington Post. â€œThe committee as a whole is pro-LGBT,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s just what I recommended wasnâ€™t accepted. So theyâ€™re focusing on individual rights.â€Outside groups have been pushing to moderate the partyâ€™s platform, especially on same-sex marriage. But itâ€™s unclear where Trump stands on some changes. His campaign has been happy to stand by and let the committee do its work.Perkins told reporters following Mondayâ€™s proceedings that this yearâ€™s platform â€• including its anti-LGBT provisions â€• are as â€œstrong asâ€ the document that delegates passed in 2012. He said the amendments passed in his committee represent â€œwhere most Republicans areâ€ on policy.But Tennessee delegate Connie Hunter did not sound as approving. She found the amendments passed by the committee on Monday â€œa bit exclusionary,â€ and worried delegates were overly specific.â€œWell, theyâ€™re probably not going to read it because itâ€™s going to be so long so it probably doesnâ€™t matter,â€ Hunter told HuffPost, when asked if she felt the measures would ostracize voters. â€œThereâ€™s nobody thatâ€™s going to read this big olâ€™ platform.â€S.V. Date contributed reporting.Editorâ€™s note: Donald Trump regularly incites political violence and is a serial liar, rampant xenophobe, racist, misogynist and birther who has repeatedly pledged to ban all Muslims â€• 1.6 billion members of an entire religion â€• from entering the U.S.

headline: Atlanta Police Applauded For 'Exemplary' Behavior During Massive Protest
short descr: America, take note.
image_caption(s): Thousands rallied in Atlanta Friday to speak out against the police violence on black lives.
article: An estimated 10,000 people flooded the streets of Atlanta, Georgia, on Friday for a massive Black Lives Matter march that remained largely peaceful and contained. There was no violence reported and only three arrests were made, according to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. The protest, which was against the recent police killings of black lives, was organized in part by the local NAACP chapter who praised police for practicing â€œexemplaryâ€ behavior during the demonstration. The organization told the AJC they contacted the city prior to the protest to inform them of their plans, and applauded Atlanta officers for their patience and â€œrestraint.â€ â€œThey were patient and sensitiveâ€¦ (even when) it sort of got away from us,â€ Richard Rose, the president of Atlantaâ€™s NAACP chapter, told the paper. â€œWe started great for the first couple of hours, then the frustrationâ€¦ and the outrage was tough to contain. The police showed restraint.â€One Atlanta resident recorded a powerful moment on camera showing a hoard of protesters yelling chants as they marched through city: Around 200 Atlanta police officers along with Georgia State Patrol officers were deployed to help cover the protest, none of whom were equipped with or dressed in riot gear. â€œIf itâ€™s not necessary, then many times it is advantageous to have normally uniformed officers in place,â€ Atlanta Police Major T Darin Schierbaum told the AJC. â€œThe key is our continuing effort to build relationships with the community â€” to know and be in dialog with community groups when there are not times of tension,â€ he said. â€œAtlanta historically is an area of peaceful protests. The police department trains for that, trains for not taking a confrontational stance.â€America, take note.

headline: Draymond Green Reportedly Arrested On Assault Charges
short descr: He was booked in his home state of Michigan.
image_caption(s): Draymond Green was reportedly arrested in Michigan over the weekend.
article: Golden State Warriors forward Draymond Green was arrested on assault charges Sunday in East Lansing, Michigan.Few details about the incident have yet to emerge. But according to court documents, Green, 26, was arrested on Sunday morning at approximately 2:38 a.m. Police told ESPN on Monday afternoon that the arrest stemmed from an altercation between Green and another man at an East Lansing restaurant. No injuries were reported, and the Warriors player was released later that day after posting bond of $200. MLive.com first reported the news of Greenâ€™s assault.Lt. Scott Wrigglesworth, the public information officer for the East Lansing Police Department, wouldnâ€™t refer to Green by name when contacted by The Huffington Post, but said that the NBA player must return to East Lansing within 10 days for his arraignment. At that time, more information will be released. In a statement, the Warriors said the team was â€œawareâ€ of the situation, but little else. â€œAt this point, we are collecting information and will have no further comment until we have a better understanding of the situation,â€ the team said.Green, a Michigan native who once starred for the Michigan Stateâ€™s menâ€™s basketball team, was a pivotal member of the Warriorsâ€™ 2015 title run and is slated to compete in the 2016 Rio Olympics next month as a member of the U.S. menâ€™s basketball team. Green was unavailable for comment on Monday morning, per MLive.com. When reached for comment by USA Today Sportsâ€™ Sam Amick, USA Basketball Director Jerry Colangelo declined to comment.Maxwell Strachan contributed reporting.

headline: Corporate Lobbyist Jumps Into Senate Race To Replace Retiring Lobbyist
short descr: And it's good news for Democrats.
image_caption(s): Evan Bayh, who previously served as U.S. senator from Indiana, is now jumping into the 2016 race to retake the seat.
article: WASHINGTON - A Democratic corporate lobbyist is jumping into a Senate race to fill a seat made vacant by the retirement of a Republican corporate lobbyist. The news is a major boon to Democrats, who are looking to retake the Senate, and also to people looking for evidence that the political system is deeply corrupt. The general practice of rotating from public office into the private sector and back again is deeply ingrained, but one particular Indiana Senate seat has hosted more than its share of special interest romps. Since at least 1989, the seat has been occupied by either a former or a soon-to-be lobbyist.Republican Dan Coats retired from his decade of service in the Senate in 1999 and became a lobbyist for banks, weapons makers and large technology firms. (Coats had been appointed to replace Dan Quayle, who gave up the seat to become the most ridiculed vice president of the second half of the 20th century.) He was replaced by Democrat Evan Bayh, the son of an extraordinarily popular progressive senator, Birch Bayh.When Evan Bayh retired from the Senate in 2010, Coats returned to the seat. And now Coats is retiring a second time, so the seat is again available, and Bayh wants it. If Bayh wins, that means the seatâ€™s occupancy, dating to the 1960s, will go Bayh-Quayle-Coats-Bayh-Coats-Bayh.Evan Bayh went out the first time with a widely read column in The New York Times condemning the Senateâ€™s dysfunction and promising heâ€™d be returning to Indiana to teach. â€œI want to be engaged in an honorable line of work,â€ he said in an interview at the time. He quickly thought better of it, and instead signed on with McGuireWoods, where he joined the lobbying campaign to repeal the medical device tax, which plays a role in financing the Affordable Care Act. A deficit scold while in the Senate, Bayh as a lobbyist was involved in two marquee efforts to jack up the deficit. (Bayh did not officially register as a lobbyist, as many at his high level decline to do.) Bayh, apparently soothed of his concern about political dysfunction, signed up as a contributor to Fox News. He then joined the private equity firm Apollo and pushed against efforts to close the carried-interest loophole, which famously allows money managers to pay laughably low tax rates by pretending their income isnâ€™t income, but instead comes from capital gains, even if they donâ€™t put up their own money. In addition, Bayh signed up with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the nationâ€™s largest corporate lobby, to lead a PR campaign in opposition to regulations promulgated by the Obama administration. This effort sought to roll back or block the implementation of regulations at the Environmental Protection Agency, Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Securities and Exchange Commission and the newly created Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.Given Bayhâ€™s family legacy and his own popularity, he has a reasonable shot at retaking the seat now, which would mean Democrats would control both Senate seats from Indiana despite the state typically trending Republican. Because of the way the Senate gives disproportionate power to small, rural states, which trend conservative â€• Alaska and California, for instance, have the same level of representation â€• Democrats, in order to control the chamber, need to hold on to seats in unlikely states such as Indiana. That puts progressives in the unpleasant position of rooting for a former senator who spent his political career calling for cuts to social spending and to programs like Medicare and Social Security, and who also spent his private years advocating for regressive policies. (At least thereâ€™s the benefit that disclosure forms will require Bayh to let the public know just how lucrative his decision not to go into teaching was.)Baron Hill, who had been the Democratic nominee for the seat, was trailing in the race badly and announced Monday that he would step aside, which will allow Bayh to take his place on the ballot. Hill shouldnâ€™t have a hard time finding his next gig. He was a registered lobbyist working in opposition to the medical device tax as recently as February. As Bayh wrote about the dysfunctions of Congress in his farewell op-ed in The New York Times, â€œSpecial interests are entrenched.â€Like this story? headline: Melissa Harris-Perry Joins BET As Special Correspondent
short descr: The former MSNBC host has a new gig.
