article: Former MSNBC host Melissa Harris-Perry is joining BET News as a special correspondent, the network announced Monday.The Wake Forest University professor and Elle.com editor-at-large will appear on several BET News programs and will develop longform programs for the network, Deadline reports. Her first assignment will be co-anchoring the networkâ€™s political convention coverage later this month with fellow BET correspondent Marc Lamont Hill. Harris-Perry tweeted on Monday that she was â€œthrilledâ€ about her new role:Harris-Perry, who hosted a weekend morning show on MSNBC for four years, left the network earlier this year after her show was pre-empted multiple times for election coverage. â€œAfter four years of building an audience, developing a brand, and developing trust with our viewers, we were effectively and utterly silenced,â€ she wrote in a letter to her staff. â€œNow, MSNBC would like me to appear for four inconsequential hours to read news that they deem relevant without returning to our team any of the editorial control and authority that makes MHP Show distinctive.â€â€œThe purpose of this decision seems to be to provide cover for MSNBC, not to provide voice for MHP Show,â€ she continued. â€œI will not be used as a tool for their purposes. I am not a token, mammy, or little brown bobble head.â€

headline: Republicans Left Wondering If Donald Trump Will Kill The Party Or Just Maim It
short descr: The party of Lincoln contemplates how to take the reins from the party of Trump.
image_caption(s): Republican activists wonder how they can retake control of their party in the aftermath of Donald Trump's nomination. Trump has won over a plurality of GOP primary voters with an agenda that has little in common with the party's longtime goals.
article: WASHINGTON â€• Next week, the party of â€œfour score and seven years agoâ€ and â€œMr. Gorbechev, tear down this wallâ€ is set to become the party of Iâ€™m building a wall and the judge is Mexican.Real estate developer-turned-reality TV star Donald Trump, barring an unlikely revolt by convention delegates in the coming days, will officially become the Republican nominee for president of the United States.The party founded to abolish slavery, and which five decades ago became the home of modern conservatism, will be led for at least the next four months, and possibly the next eight years, by a bullying entertainer with a checkered business record, little apparent knowledge or interest in governing, a long history of insults toward women and marginalized ethnic groups, and a professed admiration for dictators.â€œThe Republican Party is supposed to be the party of conservative principles. Whatâ€™s happening right now is a meltdown of the Republican Party,â€ said New Jerseyâ€™s Steve Lonegan, who supported Texas Sen. Ted Cruzâ€™s bid for the nomination and is now running a super PAC to help party activists trying to strip Trump of the nomination at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.â€œWeâ€™re going to be looking at this for years, trying to understand this,â€ he added. â€œIt will be analyzed in the books for a decade or two or three.â€Republicans like Lonegan, of course, have a more immediate question: What now?How does a party that sent Abraham Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, Dwight Eisenhower and Ronald Reagan to the Oval Office retake control from a man who has compared his fears of venereal diseases with fighting in a war and who accused the last Republican president of intentionally lying to the country to win support for an invasion â€• but who went on to win the nomination anyway?â€œI cannot in good conscience support someone that I know will be a disaster for our nation and our party,â€ said Beau Correll, a Virginia convention delegate who is suing that state to invalidate a law requiring him to vote according to the result of the March 1 primary, which Trump won.â€œIf we continue with Trump, itâ€™s going to be total annihilation,â€ he said.Many Republicans also worry that Trumpâ€™s disorganized campaign and high disapproval ratings make a victory all but impossible, but others have an even more fundamental concern.â€œThereâ€™s even a greater fear,â€ one Republican National Committee member said. â€œWhat if he really gets elected? Now what do we do?â€Other Republicans are less shy about that possibility. It would be a catastrophe, they say, and it cannot be allowed to happen.â€œWhatever Hillary Clintonâ€™s faults, sheâ€™s not ignorant or hateful or a nut,â€ wrote Mark Salter, who was a senior strategist to Arizona Sen. John McCainâ€™s 2008 presidential campaign. â€œShe acts like an adult, and understands the responsibilities of an American president.â€In such a partisan time, and with as polarizing an opponent as Clinton, relatively few Republicans are likely to openly back the other side. Preventing Trump from remaking the party in his own image, however, is a much more readily accepted goal across the GOPâ€™s spectrum.â€œThis is a pivotal moment in history,â€ said Kendal Unruh, the Colorado leader of the â€œFree the Delegatesâ€ movement to encourage fellow delegates to modify the convention rules in the coming week to dump Trump.Yet reaching a consensus on what should replace Trumpâ€™s agenda could prove more difficult than imagined â€• for the same reasons that Trump was able to win the nomination in the first place. Trumpâ€™s victories in the primaries revealed an enormous gulf between what GOP leaders believe their voters want and what those voters actually want.All of Trumpâ€™s rivals for the nomination hit the usual themes that appeal to the Republican â€œthree-legged stool.â€ They warned social conservatives about threats to religious freedom, guaranteed economic conservatives big tax cuts and rallied foreign-policy conservatives with promises of a more aggressive use of the military.Meanwhile, Trump smashed the stool until it shattered, focusing his campaign largely on building a wall along the United Statesâ€™ border with Mexico, raising tariffs, and bombing and torturing terrorists and their families.The message resonated with the rarely acknowledged fourth leg of that allegorical stool: a segment of the white population, disproportionately Southern and disproportionately undereducated, that has little interest in lower capital gains taxes or fewer business regulations.Rather, Trumpâ€™s racially tinged promise to â€œmake America great againâ€ harkens back to a time when a high school diploma, and sometimes not even that, was all that was necessary to make a middle-class living in a country that was overwhelmingly white.â€œWhat they want to do is go back to 1956. And itâ€™s just not going to happen,â€ said Mac Stipanovich, a longtime Republican consultant who served as former Florida Gov. Jeb Bushâ€™s campaign manager in 1994. â€œIf thatâ€™s who we are, then weâ€™re headed for the ash heap of history.â€Unfortunately for Republicans like Stipanovich, those white, working-class, resentful-of-how-America-has-changed voters appear to make up between 25 and 35 percent of the Republican base. They are the thousands of supporters who fill gyms and arenas around the country to take in Trump rallies. They are the reason the South, despite its high proportion of religious conservatives, supported a thrice-married New Yorker with a shaky theological background who has said he has never sought Godâ€™s forgiveness.Should the â€œDump Trumpâ€ activists succeed in the days ahead, the party faces the real possibility that the millions of GOP voters who support Trump will stay home in November, almost certainly guaranteeing a Democratic Senate and possibly even a Democratic House.â€œIf they try to yank it from him, it would be utterly catastrophic for them,â€ said Norm Ornstein, a scholar at the conservative-leaning American Enterprise Institute. â€œYou would have at least 1,000 delegates on the floor who were strong supporters of his go ballistic. There would be blood on the floor. It would be a bigger disaster for them than swallowing hard and running with Trump on the ticket.â€That Trump will lose this fall seems a foregone conclusion to the anti-Trump Republicans. The only question is by how much, and whether the size of that defeat will affect how quickly and effectively the party can rebuild for coming elections.Stipanovich believes it would be best for Trump to lose big â€• to be â€œclubbed like a baby seal,â€ as he likes to put it.â€œThereâ€™s been this mythology that the reason we havenâ€™t won big races is because we havenâ€™t been crazy enough,â€ he said, adding that a crushing loss should teach a valuable lesson. â€œI hope this puts that to rest. ... Itâ€™ll be good for the party in the long-term. To get this idea that â€˜we have to be crazy in order to winâ€™ out of our system.â€Lonegan is not sure about that theory. A blow-out Trump loss would endanger Republican control of both chambers of Congress, in his view. The only path to take back the White House is replacing Trump at the convention with an actual conservative candidate who has a fighting chance of beating Clinton, Lonegan said, adding that such a candidate would, win or lose, certainly help retain the Senate and House.In any event, an aggressive â€œDump Trumpâ€ movement will at the very least start the post-election reconstruction process.â€œItâ€™s a necessary battle because we can lay the groundwork for rebuilding,â€ Lonegan said. â€œI think the country benefits when you have a liberal Democratic Party and a conservative Republican Party.â€The two views reflect the stark split between the partyâ€™s establishment and cultural wings. It was the establishment group â€• including allies of Jeb Bush and his brother, former President George W. Bush â€• that wrote the â€œautopsyâ€ of Mitt Romneyâ€™s 2012 loss. That 2013 â€œGrowth and Opportunity Projectâ€ report urged an immigration overhaul that provided legal status to some 11 million undocumented immigrants. In the view of the authors, a more inclusive party that drew in Latinos and members of other racial groups was the only long-term solution.But that, according to Lonegan and others in the Cruz wing, was exactly the wrong approach. The Senateâ€™s failed â€œGang of Eightâ€ legislation helped alienate the voting base, as did the inability of a Republican-led House and Senate to repeal President Barack Obamaâ€™s health care law or cut spending or follow through on any of the other promises they made in the 2010 and 2014 midterms to block Obamaâ€™s agenda.GOP voters could be forgiven for seeing little difference between the parties, Lonegan said.â€œTo the average voter, it all looks the same in Washington,â€ he said.On the far side of that intraparty chasm, the establishment wing blames that all-or-nothing, no-compromise tone for setting unreasonable expectations in the first place, and Cruz is seen as Exhibit A for how not to move the party forward â€• sort of a Trump figure with a somewhat more civil tongue.This rift should sound familiar to those following the GOP in recent years. Itâ€™s been cleaving the party since the George H.W. Bush presidency 25 years ago, and has become an open civil war since the second George W. Bush term a decade ago. In that period, Republicans have lost the popular vote in five of the last six presidential elections. Stipanovich wondered when the message that the party needs to grow its base, not retreat into it, will sink in.â€œI donâ€™t know how many more times that we need to go to the polls before we convince them of that,â€ he said.To Ornstein â€• who over the years has come to believe that a dysfunctional Republican Party is largely to blame for official Washingtonâ€™s failure to solve the nationâ€™s biggest problems â€• the party factionsâ€™ inability to agree on how to deal with Trump foreshadows the difficulty they will face regrouping after November.The worst possible outcome for Lincolnâ€™s party: It will have learned nothing from its hostile takeover by a celebrity entertainer with a gift for loudly repeating the things its voting base wants to hear, Ornstein said.Unfortunately, the way battle lines are being drawn already, and with the all-but-certain-to-continue agitation by talk show hosts and others in the conservative ecosystem, the same factors that allowed a Trump nomination will remain in place after November, Ornstein predicted.â€œI just donâ€™t see any resolution to this for a long time,â€ he said.Editorâ€™s note: Donald Trump regularly incites political violence and is a serial liar, rampant xenophobe, racist, misogynist and birther who has repeatedly pledged to ban all Muslims â€• 1.6 billion members of an entire religion â€• from entering the U.S.

headline: Off-Duty Cop Kills Home Intruder Who Posted Online Threats, Police Say
short descr: "Itâ€™s very likely that this is a mental, an emotional crisis he was going through."
image_caption(s): An off-duty officer shot and killed Tyler Gebhard, 20, on Saturday after Gebhard allegedly forced his way into the man's home.
article: Police say an off-duty officer shot and killed a black man who broke into the officerâ€™s home in Lakeshire, Missouri, shortly after posting online threats against him and others.Tyler Gebhard, 20, who police say was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and schizophrenia, arrived at the unnamed officerâ€™s home Saturday afternoon acting â€œvery violent and very alarming,â€ according to St. Louis County police.Gebhard knew the officer and his family through a churchâ€™s youth group program, but itâ€™s not clear why he showed up at their home, media relations Officer Benjamin Granda told The Huffington Post Monday.Gebhardâ€™s uncle, Patrick Brogan, told the St. Louis Post-Dispatch that the shooting happened after Gebhard got into an argument with the officer on Facebook about the Black Lives Matter movement. Granda told HuffPost that police have found no information to support that claim.Police said Gebhard first started ringing the familyâ€™s doorbell around 6 p.m. When he wasnâ€™t welcomed inside, he went around to the back of the house, picked up a 120-pound concrete planter and threw it through a glass window.â€œIt kind of speaks volumes of not only his mental state, but his size and his ability,â€ Granda said.The officerâ€™s wife, mother-in-law and two children barricaded themselves in a bedroom and called 911 as the officer confronted Gebhard. Eventually, the officerâ€™s wife and children escaped by climbing through a window, Granda said.The officer gave Gebhard several verbal warnings before shooting him twice in the chest, according to the Post-Dispatch. Gebhard was pronounced dead at a hospital.Police claimed that Gebhard had made threatening online statements to various people, including the officerâ€™s family, in the final days and hours of his life. Granda said Gebhardâ€™s recent behavior was likely due to him not taking his medication.â€œItâ€™s very likely that this is a mental, an emotional crisis he was going through, because he had no criminal record and this seemed to be out of his character,â€ he said. â€œIt is pretty clear that whatever he had going on, his behavior when he got to the home was very violent and very alarming.â€Gebhardâ€™s Facebook timeline in the days leading up to the shooting includes a mix of viral videos, comedy memes and reposted messages about police violence, racism and politics, including critiques of both Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. He also shared images that denounced prejudice and that praised civil rights leaders and the Black Lives Matter movement.Photos on Facebook show Gebhard participating in charity, sports and university events.Brogan told the Post-Dispatch that Gebhard had attended Southeast Missouri State University, and confirmed that he had bipolar disorder.He said his nephew supported Black Lives Matter but did not actively participate in protests. He said that Gebhard struggled with his mental health and that his family â€œhad to stay on him to take his medication.â€â€œHe had a lot of mental problems the last few months,â€ Brogan told the Post-Dispatch. â€œA lot of difficulties in life.â€One image that Gebhard reposted, just a day before he died, reads: â€œIf u mourn the death of #AltonSterling & #PhilandoCastile but u celebrate the death of cops. Youâ€™ve just become the thing that you hate.â€St. Louis County Police Chief Jon Belmar told reporters Saturday that the officer who killed Gebhard is a three-year veteran of the department. The officer, whose race has not been reported, is now on administrative leave. This story has been updated to include Grandaâ€™s comments.

article: A group of burglars used a stolen truck to ram the side of a gun store and loot an arsenal of weapons, according to police in Texas.The suspects left a gaping hole in the side of Shooterâ€™s Edge Gun Store in Waxahachie on Sunday. A message on the storeâ€™s website read as follows:We are CLOSED until further notice.The shop also posted a pair of images to Facebook showing the damage to the building:The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives confirmed that â€œ12 handguns, 3 AR style high powered rifles, 1AK style high powered rifle and 1 shotgun were reported stolen,â€ according to ABC affiliate WFAA.Chuck Edge, who owns the store, told the station he was concerned about the incident.â€œThis was not your law abiding citizen who got a background check so now those weapons are out there,â€ he said.Police located the vehicle, but not the stolen firearms, The Dallas Morning News reports.Anyone with information about the incident is asked to call Waxahachie police at 469-309-4400.

headline: Tech CEO Celebrates Marissa Mayer For All The Wrong Reasons
short descr: Working 24/7 shouldnâ€™t be an automatic badge of honor.
image_caption(s): Max Levchin, PayPal cofounder and chief executive officer of Affirm.
article: Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer is so committed to her job that just minutes after giving birth she was back to work, a friend and Silicon Valley entrepreneur recently boasted. â€œ[Mayer] is by far the hardest working person in Silicon Valley,â€ Max Levchin told Pandoâ€™s Sarah Lacy. â€œShe gave birth to twins and then traded emails with me about a feature of a product she was launching in a week, within, from what I could tell, 20 minutes of giving birth,â€ said the PayPal cofounder, speaking before a group of people. The audience tittered. â€œShe is intensely committed to her cause. Sheâ€™s awesome,â€ said Levchin, who is now devoted mainly to a new consumer finance startup called Affirm. He also talked about how much he respects Mayer for being a pioneer and one of the few women to ascend to such a high level in tech. â€œShe is a woman who rose through the ranks in the male-dominated world,â€ he said. â€œI think thatâ€™s pretty special.â€Levchinâ€™s comments do more than just celebrate his friend, though. Applauding such an extreme work ethic sends a pretty clear message to those interested in growing and developing their careers: Work all the time and give up everything if you want to succeed. Every time an influential person makes a statement like Levchinâ€™s â€• celebrating someoneâ€™s obvious personal sacrifice, it sets both men and women back just a bit. If work culture demands us to always put work first â€• even during precious once-in-a-lifetime moments â€• then weâ€™re all in trouble. Whatâ€™s also troubling about Levchinâ€™s comments is that he would never have made them about a man. A male CEO who sends a work email just moments after his wife gave birth would hardly be remarkable.Because, first: thatâ€™s expected. And second, women, particularly mothers, are held to some truly impossible standards. Some will judge you as a bad mother for working so soon after giving birth (and many have judged Mayer). Others will see this as a sign youâ€™re a great worker.But really itâ€™s neither of those things. Putting in long hours and sacrificing your personal life doesnâ€™t necessarily mean youâ€™re a great worker or, on the flip side, doing anything wrong in the parenting realm.Working 24/7 just means youâ€™ve given in to the absurd cult of overwork. Thereâ€™s really no need to celebrate that fact.On a personal level, the massive downsides to the cult are obvious: No one dies regretting that they didnâ€™t work more, is the old cliche. Time with your new baby or your kids is time you will never ever get back.Professionally speaking, more people are realizing that working all the time doesnâ€™t lead to excellence. It can often lead to burnout and poor decision making. It can lead more workers to quit their jobs or suffer from work-related stress. More often, the pressure to always be on â€• to respond to emails during childbirth, in the middle of the night, from your kidsâ€™ graduation â€• means we get trapped in what one researcher at the Harvard Business School calls, â€œthe cycle of responsiveness.â€â€œWe donâ€™t think about better, faster, and more effective ways of working,â€ Leslie Perlow wrote for Harvard Business Review in 2012. â€œRather, we just keep working more and more, perpetuating and amplifying the bad intensity in our work â€” those unnecessary iterations, the lack of communication and alignment, the last-minute, late-night changes and those weekend â€œemergenciesâ€ that get in the way of doing our best at work and having time for life outside of work.â€Taking breaks and time off can be good for your productivity, giving you time to pull back from the minutia of the everyday to focus on more big picture thinking.â€œOur research shows that being always available is actually dysfunctional for everyone at some level,â€ Erin Reid, an assistant professor at Boston Universityâ€™s Questrom School of Business, recently told The Huffington Post. Yet, many workplaces donâ€™t value time off â€• instead reinforcing a culture of hard-charging overwork, as evidenced by Levchinâ€™s remarks. At another point in the interview he and Lacy joke about how during PayPalâ€™s early days, Levchin would work next to a box of T-shirts. Heâ€™d pull an all-nighter, stink up a shirt and then pull another one out of the box. â€œItâ€™s really not your body that smells,â€ he said, to explain why this is an effective strategy to avoid stinking. For a recent research paper, Reid looked at a consulting firm where overwork was so expected, men just lied and pretended to work 80 hour weeks in order to get ahead. If they were upfront about their commitment to family â€• and sometimes prioritized their personal lives â€• they were penalized with fewer promotions.Iâ€™m not here to judge Mayer for working right after childbirth. She was already put through the wringer after announcing sheâ€™d work throughout her two week long maternity leave. She runs a public company â€• one thatâ€™s going through a very rocky time â€• and she can choose to structure her life any way she wants. Sheâ€™s only one of an extremely rare breed â€• a female CEO in the Fortune 500. There are only about 20 other women on that list.Mayer herself has been open about her choices and the fact that she is, truly, exceptional â€• as one of the very few young female CEOs out there. But if we continue to only laud and value women and men who work 24/7 as the best kind of workers, weâ€™ll probably continue to have only about 20 women on the Fortune 500. Because, itâ€™s often women who must make a choice: Send emails 20 minutes after giving birth, or slow down your career trajectory. Many of us choose the exit lane.The idea that we need to celebrate overwork and hold that up as exemplifying some kind of gold standard of work, though, is the issue.Why didnâ€™t Levchin talk about an amazing insight or decision Mayerâ€™s made? No one remembers Steve Jobs for his overwork, but for his ideas. Ideas donâ€™t always require you to work at 2 a.m. on a Saturday or while nursing your infant.Yet, in certain circles, sacrificing your personal life â€• working flat out at all hours â€• still signifies that youâ€™re a good worker. Thatâ€™s sure to be a turn-off to a lot of people picking a career track.If the tech industry is serious about its commitment to hire more diverse workers â€• people of color, women, older workers, parents â€• they canâ€™t send the message that working in the industry requires a complete disavowal of your life.Unless thatâ€™s truly what it takes.

headline: Thousands Gather At Ceremony For Victims Of Srebrenica Massacre
short descr: Survivors said those who denied a genocide had occurred were not welcome at the event.
image_caption(s): Nationalist Bosnian Serb forces killed 8,000 Bosniaks after overrunning Srebrenica near the end of Bosniaâ€™s war 21 years ago.
article: SREBRENICA, Bosnia (Reuters) - Thousands of Muslim Bosniaks paid respect to 127 victims of the 1995 Srebrenica massacre buried in individual graves on Monday in a ceremony avoided by Serbs after survivors said they were not welcome because they denied genocide had occurred.Nationalist Bosnian Serb forces led by General Ratko Mladic executed 8,000 Bosniak men and boys after overrunning Srebrenica near the end of Bosniaâ€™s war 21 years ago and dumped their bodies in pits - Europeâ€™s worst atrocity since World War Two.Serb forces subsequently dug up the bodies and scattered them in a systematic effort to conceal the crime. U.N. war crimes investigators later excavated the mass graves, but over 1,000 bodies are still missing.Most Serbs, both in Bosnia and Serbia whose 1990s leadership armed and funded Bosnian Serb forces, strongly deny that the massacre was genocide as judged by the U.N. war crimes tribunal for former Yugoslavia.They dispute the death toll and the official account of what happened, reflecting conflicting narratives about how and why Yugoslavia broke up in bloodshed. That divide continues to hinder reconciliation and stifle Bosniaâ€™s progress toward integration with Western Europe. The Balkan country today is split into autonomous Serb and Bosniak-Croat entities.For Muslim Bosniaks, Srebrenica has become a symbol of collective suffering and July burials of victims an annual ritual. To give people with HIV their best shot at survival and to stop the virus from spreading, patients should be treated much earlier than has previously been the case in developing countries, according to new guidelines issued Sunday June 30, 2013 at an AIDS meeting in Malaysia by the World Health Organization. article: JOHANNESBURG, July 11 (Reuters) - The United States on Monday pledged $410 million towards ending the AIDS epidemic in South Africa, the country hardest hit.South Africa has the worldâ€™s largest population of people living with HIV, at 6.8 million, and the funds will help expand its antiretroviral programme, which provides treatment to more than 3 million patients.The country experienced 180,000 AIDS-related deaths in 2015, according to the United Nations Program on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS). Its prevalence rate of HIV among adults, at 19 percent, is one of the highest in the world.The funds were donated through the U.S. Presidentâ€™s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), which also supports projects in South Africa to encourage male circumcision and attempts to reduce new HIV infections in girls and young women.Delegates are expected to discuss the ambitious target, proposed by UNAIDS, of ending AIDS as a global health crisis by 2030 at the International AIDS Conference to be held in the South African coastal city of Durban next week.Health Minister Aaron Motsoaledi said while the government expected to take on a larger share of the financial burden of HIV treatment and prevention, it depended on support from the international community.â€œWe mustnâ€™t say that just because we are making progress the job is done,â€ he said. â€œThe job is far from done.â€In May, Motsoaledi said South Africa recorded half of the 5,000 new infections a week among young women out of 14 southern and Eastern African countries.Pretoria set up a new state-owned pharmaceutical firm last year to help cut the cost of HIV treatment. In December 2014, South Africa chose four drug companies, including Indiaâ€™s Cipla and local firm Aspen Pharmacare, to make and supply anti-retrovirals to public hospitals. headline: Vatican Selects Former Fox News Reporter As New Spokesman
short descr: Greg Burke will replace Father Federico Lombardi as the pope's official spokesperson.
image_caption(s): Father Federico Lombardi, right, will step down after serving as Holy See spokesman for the past 10 years.
article: The Vatican named former Fox News reporter Greg Burke as its new spokesman on Monday, the first time a U.S. citizen has been entrusted with leading the popeâ€™s communications team.Burke, who is a member of the conservative Catholic group Opus Dei, was hired by the Vatican as an adviser four years ago at a time when the Roman Catholic Church was mired in leaks scandals and stuck in a public relations quagmire.On Monday, the Vatican announced that Burke would become the popeâ€™s official spokesman, with Father Federico Lombardi stepping down from the role which he had held for 10 years.Spanish radio reporter Paoloma Garcia Ovejero will become the deputy spokesperson â€• the first time a woman has had such a senior role in the Vatican communications department.Burke, 56, a native of St Louis, Missouri, was Foxâ€™s Rome-based roving correspondent for Europe and the Middle East before joining the Vatican. Prior to that he worked for Time magazine in the Italian capital for a decade.He worked as a stringer for Reuters in Rome early in his career and has also written several books, one about an Italian soccer team.(Reporting by Crispian Balmer; Editing by Alison Williams)

headline: Angela Eagle Challenges Corbyn For Leadership Of UK Labour Party
authors: William James and Estelle Shirbon, Reuters
short descr: The stage is now set for a heated fight for control of Britain's opposition party.
image_caption(s): Britain's former Labour Party Business policy chief Angela Eagle will challenge Jeremy Corbyn for leadership of the UK Labour Party.
article: LONDON, July 11 (Reuters) - British opposition Labour lawmaker Angela Eagle launched her bid to take over the leadership of the party on Monday, saying current leader Jeremy Corbyn was not up to the task of defeating the ruling Conservatives.The challenge marks the latest in a struggle for control of Britainâ€™s second-largest political party triggered by the June 23 vote to leave the European Union - which many in Labour have blamed on Corbyn, saying he didnâ€™t campaign hard enough.The outcome of the leadership contest, seen as a battle between the partyâ€™s hard left and more moderate factions, will define Labourâ€™s voice in the negotiations to set the terms of Britainâ€™s EU exit.â€œToday I am announcing my decision to stand for the leadership of the Labour Party,â€ said Eagle. â€œI am a practical socialist driven by a strong set of values who wants to get things done.â€The partyâ€™s general secretary later confirmed the leadership contest had officially been triggered and said the timetable would be set out after a meeting of Labourâ€™s national executive committee.The contest, in which Corbyn has said he will stand again, comes amid calls for a fresh national election as the Conservatives prepare to appoint a successor to Prime Minister David Cameron.â€œWe alone can hold this right wing Tory (Conservative) government to account and then replace it by winning a general election,â€ Eagle said. â€œJeremy Corbyn is unable to provide the leadership this huge task needs.â€Corbyn was chosen as Labour leader last year on a wave of support from the partyâ€™s most left-wing activists. But he has clashed with its lawmakers who overwhelmingly passed a no-confidence motion in his leadership.Corbynâ€™s support among the partyâ€™s ordinary members, who will elect the partyâ€™s next leader, remains strong, leading some lawmakers and commentators to speculate the leadership contest may split the party.(Additional reporting by Ana Nicolaci da Costa and Karin Strohecker,; editing by Stephen Addison)
